questions.text: A young woman enters puberty with around 40,000 primary ovum cells in her ovary. How many of these primary ova are ovulated during her reproductive life?
questions.solution:
Option C: 480

  • During puberty, at the time of ovulation, meiosis I completed, and the primary oocyte is converted to a secondary oocyte and first polar body.
  • After fertilization, the second polar body and ovum are released.
  • A mature ovum is released from the ovary during ovulation.
  • During her reproductive period, a woman will ovulate approximately 480 ova.
  • A woman will ovulate 12 primary ova per year as long as she is not taking oral contraceptives, does not become pregnant, or does not have any anovulatory cycle.
  • Assuming that a reproductive time of 40 years gives 40 x12 = 480 ova.

Option A: 40,000

  •  
  • The hormonal changes in the young woman stimulate the ovarian and menstrual cycles; 5 to 15 oocytes will then begin maturation to form ova with each ovarian cycle throughout the woman’s reproductive life.
  • All of the ova (40000) don't ovulate during the entire reproductive age.

Option B: 35,000

  • Most of the ovum doesn’t ovulate during the entire reproductive age, as a woman will ovulate approximately 480 ova. 

Option D: 48​​​​​​​

  • Although, all ovum doesn't ovulate during the entire reproductive age.
  • Approximately 480 ova will be ovulated, whereas the number of 48 is significantly few.

questions.text: The patient underwent partial resection of intestine after which there is major electrolyte imbalance which part of intestine is responsible for it?
questions.solution:
The resection of jejunum leads to major electrolyte imbalance because most of the fluid and electrolyte reabsorption occurs in this segment.

NOTE:

  • Almost all iron absorption occurs in the duodenum.
  • Most Vitamins are absorbed in the upper small intestine, but
  • Vitamin B12is absorbed in the ileum.
  • Vitamin B12absorption and folate absorption are Na+- independent, but all seven of the remaining water-soluble vitamins—thiamine, riboflavin, niacin, pyridoxine, pantothenate, biotin, and ascorbic acid—are absorbed by carriers that are Na+ cotransporters.
  • Folate is absorbed in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).
  • Dietary folate exists in several forms, much of it as folate polyglutamate.
  • The intestinal absorption of folate polyglutamate requires deconjugation by a brush border peptidase to folate monoglutamate, which then enters the enterocyte through a transporter.
  • Maximum water absorption takes place in the jejunum.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency department after an automobile collision. Radiographic examination reveals multiple fractures of the humerus. Flexion and supination of the forearm are severely weakened. She also has loss of sensation on the lateral surface of the forearm. Which of the following nerves has most likely been injured?
questions.solution:
The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the biceps brachii and brachialis, which are the flexors of the forearm at the elbow. The musculocutaneous nerve continues as the lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve, which supplies sensation to the lateral side of the forearm (with the forearm in the anatomic position). The biceps brachii is the most powerful supinator muscle. Injury to this nerve would result in weakness of supination and forearm flexion and lateral forearm sensory loss. Injury to the radial nerve would result in weakened extension and a characteristic wrist drop.

Injury to the median nerve causes paralysis of flexor digitorum superficialis and other flexors in the forearm and results in a characteristic flattening of the thenar eminence.

The lateral cord of the brachial plexus gives origin both to the musculocutaneous and lateral pectoral nerves. There is no indication of pectoral paralysis or weakness. Injury to the lateral cord can result in weakened flexion and supination in the forearm, and weakened adduction and medial rotation of the arm.

questions.text: A 48 years old male presented with a history of one day old injury to right ankle following an accidental fall by slipping on a slope, with the right foot being forced mainly into hyperplantar flexion and eversion. He presented with complaints of pain, swelling, deformity just distal to the ankle and proximal foot, and was unable to bear weight on right foot. Clinical examination and radiology suggestive of talocalcaneonavicular joint dislocation. What type of joint it is?
questions.solution:
Ball-and-Socket (Spheroidal) Joints: Articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). Movements occur around an indefinite number of axes which have one common centre. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely.

Examples:

a) Shoulder joint

b) Hip joint

c) Talocalcaneonavicular joint

d) Incudostapedial joint

questions.text: Type of connective tissue in arrow marked area is
questions.solution:
There are two layers in dermis-

1. Superficial areolar layer- loose connective tissue

2. Deep reticular layer- dense connective tissue

  • BothLoose and Dense connective tissuesare composed ofthree elements: an amorphous ground substance, fibres, and various types of cells.
  • TheAmorphousground substance ofLoose Connective Tissueis the medium of exchange between the connective tissue cells and the bloodstream and provides structural support for the connective tissue.
  • The lower proportion of cells to fibres is a feature of Dense Connective tissue.
  • In deep reticular layer, the collagen fibres are running in haphazard manner, so it is dense irregular connective tissue.
  • Superficial areolar layer is loose connective tissue
  • Dense irregular connective tissue seen in deep reticular layer of dermis, also seen in periosteum and perichondrium.

Types of connective tissue-

  1. Dense irregular- seen in periosteum and perichondrium
  2. Dense regular- seen in ligaments, tendons and aponeurosis
  3. Loose areolar- superficial layer of dermis and lamina propria
  4. Loose reticular

questions.text: The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? Note: The solid line is the original fluid compartment and the colour shaded compartment within the dotted line denotes the change caused by the condition.
questions.solution:
• In adrenal insufficiency there is hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Aldosterone deficiency leads to increased sodium loss (loss of hyperosmotic fluid).
  • The osmolarity of ECF decreases.
  • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume.
  • Water shifts into ICF; as a result of the shift, ICF osmolarity decreases until it is equal to ECF osmolarity, and ICF volume increases.
  • So, loss of hypertonic fluid causes hypotonic volume contraction.

questions.text: What type of enzyme regulation is depicted?
questions.solution:
•The image shows the characteristic sigmoidal curve of allosteric enzymes.

•Allosteric enzymes also contain a site other than active site which binds to allosteric regulator.

•Allosteric enzymes are usually multi-subunit enzymes.

•Binding of allosteric regulator to the allosteric site alters the affinity of active site. The affinity can be increased or decreased.

•When the substrate of the enzyme itself acts as an allosteric regulator, it is known as homotropic allosteric regulator e.g. ATP is the negative homotropic allosteric regulator of phosphofructokinase-1

•Positive allosteric regulators increase the affinity and negative allosteric regulators decreases the affinity.

•Sigmoidal curve is obtained on plotting velocity against substrate concentration similar to that of hemoglobin-oxygen dissociation curve.

•Allosteric enzymes do not obey Michalis-Menten equation. They do obey Hill’s equation. • •

questions.text: which of the following is incorrectly marked:

choices.text: Lesions in the globus pallidus - athetosis
Lesions in the categorical hemisphere – retrograde amnesia

questions.solution:
• The hippocampus (most medial portion in temporal lobe) promotes storage of memories —anterograde amnesia occurs after hippocampal lesions are sustained.
  • Lesions in the globus pallidus frequently lead to spontaneous and often continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face. These movements are called athetosis.
  • Categorical and representational hemispheres are for sequential-analytic processes and visuospatial relations, respectively. Lesions in the representational hemisphere produce astereognosis—the inability to identify objects by feeling them.
  • Aphasias are abnormalities of language functions and are caused by lesions in the categorical hemisphere. They are classified as fluent (Wernicke area), nonfluent (Broca area), and anomic (angular gyrus) based on the location of brain lesions.

questions.text: After prolonged injection of GnRH in males which of the following occurs?
questions.solution:
• GnRH has pulsatile secretion (secreted intermittently a few minutes at a time once every 1 to 3 hours). Continuous infusion of GnRH downregulates the GnRH receptor, thereby resulting in a decrease in FSH and LH secretion.
  • At high frequency (1 GnRH pulse per hour) LH secretion is favoured while at low-frequency FSH secretion is favoured.
  • Prolonged injection of GnRH in males decreases LH levels.
  • Prolonged administration of GnRH or intermittent administration of high doses of GnRH analogues suppresses the release of gonadotropin, lowers LH and FSH levels and thereby reduces testosterone production (i.e., chemical castration).
  • The mechanism is inhibition of the replenishment of GnRH receptors so that insufficient receptors are available for GnRH function.
  • Prolonged injection of GnRH in males decreases LH levels. Prolonged administration of GnRH or intermittent administration of high doses of GnRH analogues suppresses the release of gonadotropin, lowers LH and FSH levels and thereby reduces testosterone production (i.e., chemical castration).
  • The mechanism is inhibition of the replenishment of GnRH receptors so that insufficient receptors are available for GnRH function.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents in the emergency room with dizziness and nystagmus. Examination reveals a loss of pain and temperature sensation over the right side of the face and the left side of the body. The patient exhibits ataxia and intention tremor on the right in both the upper and lower extremities and is unable to perform either the finger-to-nose or heel to-shin tasks on the right. In addition, she is hoarse and demonstrates pupillary constriction ,drooping of the eyelid ,tinnitus on the right. Finally, the right side of her face is drier than the left. Which of the following artery block would explain the patient’s condition:
questions.solution:
- This is a case of right sided Wallenberg syndrome due to occlusion in the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery, leading to lateral medullary ischemia and lesion of certain nuclei and tracts.

- The patient has alternating hemi-anesthesia: ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature on face and contralateral loss of pain and temperature on the body. It occurs due to lesion of lateral spinothalamic tract and spinal sensory nucleus of trigeminal.

- Ataxia and intentions tremors indicate injury to spinocerebellar tract in the lateral medulla.

- There is hoarseness of voice which indicates lesion of nucleus ambiguus (which controls muscles of larynx).

- Patient also has features of right sided Horner syndrome due to lesion of the hypothalamo-spinal pathway in the lateral medulla.

-Patient presents with features of right sided tinnitus due to the involvement of the inferior vestibular nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Valves of Houston is TRUE

choices.text: Middle valve corresponds to the middle convex fold to the Right
Upper valve corresponds to peritoneal reflections
Valves contain all three layers of muscle wall
Valves disappear after the mobilization of rectum

questions.solution:
Explanation: Valves of Houston are lost after full mobilization of the rectum.

  • The middle valve is located on the right wall but correspond to the middle convex fold to the left.
  • The middle (not upper) valve corresponds to the level of peritoneal reflection.
  • These valves do not contain all three layers of the muscle wall.

Rectum has certain permanent transverse folds, of a semilunar (crescentic) shape, known as the transverse folds of rectum (Houston's valves).

questions.text: The order of depolarization in cardiac tissue is:
questions.solution:
The spread of Cardiac Excitation:

  • Atrial depolarization is initiated from SA node spreads radially through atria, then converges on the AV node.
  • A delay of about 0.1s (AV nodal delay) occurs before excitation spreads to the ventricles. Ventricular depolarization starts at the left side of the interventricular septum and moves first to the right across the midportion of the septum.
  • It moves along the ventricular walls to the AV groove, proceeding from the endocardial to the epicardial surface.

The sequence of depolarization in cardiac tissue.

  • Hemolysis produces a lot of urobilinogen which is excreted in urine → option a and c are excluded.
  • In hepatocellular jaundice, urobilinogen can be normal or reduced. The question specifically uses the word "absent" → options b is also excluded.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presented to a tertiary-care centre with a 1-day history of fever, headache, and bilateral periorbital and mid-facial swelling. The day prior to the onset of his symptoms, he had attempted to burst a furuncle in the inner margin of his right nostril. He had no relevant medical history and was not on any medications. Computed tomography (CT) brain (pre- and post-contrast with arteriogram and venogram) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)/MR venogram revealed engorged, thrombosed superior ophthalmic veins bilaterally with non-opacification of the cavernous sinuses, consistent with bilateral cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of the following is not true in this condition?

choices.text: Inferior ophthalmic vein can spread infection from dangerous area of face
Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause
Loss of sensation around the eye

questions.solution:
• Cavernous sinus thrombosis caused by sepsis in the dangerous area of the face, in nasal cavities & in paranasal sinuses.
  • Septic emboli carried by the superior (more common) or inferior ophthalmic veins into the cavernous sinus.

Nervous symptoms

  • Loss of sensation around the eye due to the involvement of V1 and V2 division of Vth nerve.
  • Involvement of CN III, IV, VI

Venous symptoms

  • Oedema of eyelids, cornea, root of nose d/t congestion of the orbital veins.

questions.text: A 56-year old man was ill advised by someone to take higher doses of vitamin E supplementation daily to boost his immunity. Vitamin E being a fat-soluble vitamin can accumulate in the body if higher than recommended doses are taken for prolonged periods. He might show which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin E is believed to be inhibiting protein kinase C–mediated platelet aggregation and nitric oxide production hence leading to bleeding tendencies and elevated bleeding time.
  • In patients with unexplained bruising or bleeding, it is important to review vitamin E supplementation.

Other options:

Option A: hypercalcemia occurs as a result of Vitamin D toxicity.

Option B: Raised intracranial tension (pseudotumor cerebri) occurs as a result of acute toxicity of vitamin A.

Option D: Thiamine deficiency can result in psychosis.

questions.text: Which part of the lung is most likely affected in a 68-year-old male with severe emphysema and esophageal achalasia, admitted to the intensive care unit with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure and right lower lobe pneumonia, where dullness on percussion is observed in the area medial to the medial border of the scapula upon arm elevation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Right superior Bronchopulmonary Segment

  • A broncho-pulmonary segment is a portion of the lung supplied by a specific segmental bronchus and its vessels. These arteries branch from the pulmonary and bronchial arteries and run together through the center of the segment.
  • Veins and lymphatic vessels drain along the edges of the segment. The segments are separated by layers of connective tissue that form them into discrete anatomical and functional units. This separation means that a broncho-pulmonary segment can be surgically removed without affecting the function of the others.
  • There are ten broncho-pulmonary segments in the right lung: three in the superior lobe, two in the middle lobe, and five in the inferior lobe. Some of the segments may fuse in the left lung to form usually eight to nine segments (four to five in the upper lobe and four to five in the lower lobe.
  • This is the location of the apical (superior) Broncho-pulmonary Segment (BPS) of the right lower lobe, a common site of aspiration pneumonitis.

Options B: Right posterior Bronchopulmonary Segment 

  • Upon elevation of the arm, the medial border of the scapula corresponds to the oblique fissure of the lung on the posterior thorax. Medial to that lies the apex of the lower lobe of the lung.

Option C: Left superior Broncho-pulmonary Segment

  • As right primary bronchus is shorter in length, has a wider lumen, and is more vertical hence more prone to aspiration and leading to aspiration pneumonitis.

Option D: Right medial basal Bronchopulmonary Segment

  • Upon elevation of the arm, the medial border of the scapula corresponds to the oblique fissure of the lung on the posterior thorax.
  • So, the right medial basal border is not affected.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complaining of erectile dysfunction. He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following vasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient.
  • Sildenafil: It is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the action of NO.
  • Penile erection is associated with sexual arousal caused by sexually related psychic and/or physical stimuli.
  • During sexual arousal, impulses from the genitalia, together with signals emanating from the limbic system, elicit motor impulses in the spinal cord.
  • The sacral parasympathetic fibres convey these impulses from the spinal cord, via the cavernous nerve branches of the prostatic plexus, into the penis.
  • These signals cause smooth muscle relaxation of the corpora cavernosa and dilatation of the arterioles.
  • The transmitter responsible for the relaxation of smooth muscle of the cavernosa and arterioles isnitric oxide (NO).

questions.text: A patient who is suffering from vitamin B12 deficiency produces a lot of methyl malonate (−OOC–CH(CH3)–COO−) in his body causing methyl malonyl acidemia. Methylmalonate is best described as which one of the following?

choices.text: The conjugate base of a weak acid
It is 100% dissociated at its pKa
It is a major intracellular buffer

questions.solution:
• Methylmalonic acid contains two carboxylic acid groups and is, therefore, a weak acid.
  • According to the Henderson- Hasselbalch equation, the carboxylic acid groups are 50% dissociated at their pKa (thus, B is incorrect).
  • To acts as a buffer a weak acid need to be present in partially dissociated form. However, carboxylic acid groups of weak acids usually have a pKa between 2 and 5, so this acid would be nearly fully dissociated at a blood pH of 7.4 and cannot act as a buffer at at neutral pH in the cell (thus, C is incorrect).

questions.text: Delta hepatitis only occurs in patients who also have either acute or chronic infection with hepatitis B virus. What is the characteristic of delta agent?
questions.solution:
• The delta agent is an incomplete RNA virus that requires HBsAg for replication.

HDV (Delta Agent):

  • HDV is a defective RNA virus that is dependent on host enzymes and viral enzymes of HBV for its own replication.
  • It is found most often in persons who have multiple parenteral exposures, for example,intravenous (IV) drug abusers, hemophiliacs, and multiply transfused patients.
  • Onset is insidious.

Mode of transmission:

  • Blood (most common)
  • Sexual

questions.text: You are an investigator. You want to study the effects of working nights on the incidence of a certain health problem. You collect health information on a group of 9-to-5 night workers and a group of workers doing the same kind of work, but at night. You then measure the rates at which members of both groups reported the health problem. You then conclude that night work is associated with an increase in that health problem. The type of bias is:
questions.solution:
The two groups being studied here may have been very different to begin with. The people who worked nights may have been less skilled, with fewer employment options. Their lower socioeconomic status would also be linked with more health risks due to less healthy diets, less time and money for leisure activities and so on. So the finding may not be related to night work at all, but a reflection of the influence of socioeconomic status. Selection bias is a kind of error that occurs when the researcher decides who is going to be studied. It is usually associated with research where the selection of participants isn’t random (i.e. with observational studies such as cohort, case-control and cross-sectional studies).

A is not correct

Lead time bias refers to the early diagnosis of a disease falsely making it look like people are surviving longer. In this study no examination on when the disease was detected and whether the disease could be detected at all.

C is not correct

Measurement bias refers to study between two different groups with measurement or data gathering methods differing between them. Evaluation of these two groups is in the same way by review of medical records.

D is not correct

Recall bias results from a difference between two groups in retrospective recall of past factors or outcomes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female, presented to OPD with hemoptysis and hematuria. Lab studies show the presence of anti-basement membrane antibodies. The patient undergoes plasmapheresis & her symptoms improved. Which of the following diseases is of the same hypersensitivity category as this disease?
questions.solution:
• Myasthenia gravis is of the same hypersensitivity category as this disease.
  • Given scenario suggests diagnosis of Good pasture's syndrome: Anti-glomerular basement membrane disease- anti-basement membrane antibodies specific for collagen located in glomerular and pulmonary basement membranes.
  • Myasthenia gravisis an autoimmune disease that's categorized as a type II hypersensitivity that involves autoantibodies binding acetylcholine receptors on skeletal muscle cells.
  • Good pasture's syndrome and Myasthenia gravis are type II hypersensitivity reactions.
    • Other options:
      • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Type III hypersensitivity
      • Seasonal allergies: type I hypersensitivity reactions.
      • Poison ivy rash: type IV hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: The lawyer who is defending the suspect has fought the initial trial, for the suspect to be excused under IPC 84, which was derived from McNaughton RULES. What is the basis of argument and request for excuse according to the section appealed under?
questions.solution:
Section 84 IPC:

  1. It defines Criminal responsibility of mentally ill. According to this section, nothing is an offence done by a person who is incapable of knowing that he is doing is wrong due to mental illness.
  2. The law presumes every individual to be sane and responsible for his criminal acts unless the contrary is proved in the court. In criminal cases, where mental illness is raised as a plea of exemption from liability, the burden of proving it lies on the defence.
  3. Initially, McNaughton RULES were drafted in England which laid guidelines on considering the criminal responsibility of mentally ill. The section 84 IPC is derived from these McNaughton RULES

questions.text: A man with type 2 diabetes is receiving a combination of oral drugs to maintain glycemic contro1. He becomes hypoglycemic one afternoon and ingests some table sugar and his blood glucose levels remain low, his symptoms persist. Which antidiabetic that he was taking accounted for the failure of oral sugars to restore his plasma glucose?
questions.solution:
Alpha glucosidase inhibitor, stops the conversion of sucrose to glucose. Therefore, using table sugar for treatment of hypo-glycemia when patient is on acarbose is not useful.

MOA:

  • Located in the intestinal brush border, α-glucosidase enzymes break down carbohydrates into glucose and other simple sugars that can be absorbed.
  • Acarbose and miglitol reversibly inhibit α-glucosidase enzymes.

Major s/e are flatulence, diarrhoea and abdominal cramping.

questions.text:
7 years old boy came to the hospital with throat pain. On examination, the patient presets with greyish-white membrane over the tonsils and presents with bull’s neck edema. Culture revealed Chinese letter pattern. Which of the following media are used for the growth of this bacteria?

Loeffler’s serum slope
Hoyle’s media
Macleod’s media
Thayer martin media
questions.solution:
• Culture media used for Corynebacterium Diphtheria were
    • Loeffler’s serum slope
    • Hoyle’s media
    • Macleod’s media
    • TInsdale media
  • Thayer martin media is used for meningococci and gonococci
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria are gram positive, Non-acid fast, non-motile rods with irregularly stained segments and sometimes granules.
  • Also known as Klebloffler’s bacillus

questions.text: A 6 yr old girl is brought with complaints of generalised swelling of the body. Urinary examination reveals grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty casts. She has no history of hematuria. Which of the following statements about her condition is true?

choices.text: Her C3 levels will be low
No IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy

questions.solution:
• The clinical symptoms and the findings in the stem of the question (child with generalised swelling because of reduced serum protein secondary to massive proteinuria with urinary lipid casts) are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.
  • The commonest cause in a child of nephrotic syndrome is lipoid nephrosis or minimal change disease.
  • So option ‘a’ and ‘d’ are ruled out. Both cause hematuria as a finding. Electron microscopic examination in minimal change disease show the presence of effacement of foot processes of podocytes.

questions.text: A severely obese female patient with a history of falls presents with a crown fracture of maxillary central incisors. The patient was mentally retarded. On physical examination a typical body habitus with narrow shoulders and obesity. Maternal disomy of chromosome 15 is seen. In the given disease obesity is due to:
questions.solution:
Uniparentaldisomy refers to the situation in which2 copies of a chromosome come from the same parent, instead of1 copy coming from the mother, and1 copy coming from the father.

  • Angelman syndrome can result when a baby inherits both copies of a section of chromosome #15 from the father (rather than 1 from the mother and 1 from the father).
  • Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS), on the other hand, can result when a baby inherits both copies of a section of chromosome #15 from the mother

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a genetic disorder occurring in 1 of 10,000–16,000 live births and is characterized by excessive appetite with progressive massive obesity as well as short stature and mental retardation. Most patients have GH deficiency and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (low levels of FSH, LH). The cause of obesity is thought to be due to increased levels of ghrelin.

Ghrelin

  • Growth hormone secretagogue
  • Only gut hormone with orexigenic (means increasing food intake) property.
  • Primarily produced in the stomach.
  • Important role in hyperphagia, hence affected children are obese.

IMG showing (Genomic Imprinting) leading to Prader Willi syndrome(Chr 15)

questions.text: A patient has repeated trauma over the gingival mucosa and presented to the clinician as red pedunculated lesion which bleed on touch and ulcerated, surgical excision was done and histopathological picture is given below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
Pyogenicgranulomas

  • Capillary hemangiomas that present as rapidly growing red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa.
  • They bleed easily and are often ulcerated.
  • Histologically, they are composed of thin-walled capillaries with scant stroma.

questions.text: Using a new technique, Hb was estimated in a blood sample. The test was repeated for 10 times. The reports were: 9.5, 9.2, 9.4, 9.6, 9.7, 9.9, 10.2, 10.3, 10.5 and 12.1. Accurate value of Hb was estimated by standard tests to be 10.2. The new technique has:
questions.solution:
In the given question,

Mean of 10 Hb values = Sum (9.5, 9.2, 9.4, 9.6, 9.7, 9.9, 10.2, 10.3, 10.5 and 12.1)/10 = 100/10 = 10

  • Validity means getting the right results, whether positive or negative and reliability means getting the same result every time, irrespective of whether it is right or wrong.
  • Since the results obtained by test are different than the actual value of Hb, it is not valid or accurate.
  • Also, since every time we are getting different values , the test is not reliable.

questions.text: An elderly male patient with irregular intake of hypertensive medication, underwent a renal biopsy for hypertension induced decreased renal function and arterioles show changes as depicted in pictures. What does the image depict?
questions.solution:
Hyperplastic Arteriolosclerosis:

  • Occurs in severe hypertension; Vessels exhibit concentric, laminated (“onion- skin”) thickening of the walls with luminal narrowing. 
  • The laminations consist of smooth muscle cells with thickened, reduplicated basement membrane
  • In malignant hypertension, they are accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arteriolitis).

questions.text: A 30 year old female visited to the OPD with concern of her increasing weight and difficulty in breathing while performing physical exercise. She informed the doctor that she has a family history of heart disease. What is the Goal of Prudent diet for prevention of Coronary heart disease?
questions.solution:
• Goal of WHO Prudent diet is to Reduce Cholesterol: HDL ratio <3.5
  • Prudent diet: Dietary modification is the principle preventive strategy in the prevention of CHD.
  • WHO recommended changes:
    • Reduction of fat intake to <20-30% of total energy intake
    • Consumption of saturated fats <7% of total energy intake
    • Reduction in cholesterol intake to <200 mg/day
    • Increase in complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Reduction of salt intake to < 5 gms per day
    • Avoidance of alcohol consumption

Extra edge:

Balanced diet contain: [carbohydrates> fats> proteins]

  • Proteins -10-15 % of daily energy intake [met first]
  • Fats - 15-30 %
  • Carbohydrates - constitute remaining energy.

questions.text: An 87-year-old man has profound bleeding from a peptic ulcer and dies of hypovolemic shock. The liver at autopsy displays centrilobular necrosis. Compared to viable hepatocytes, the necrotic cells contain higher intracellular concentrations of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Coagulative necrosis is characterized by a massive influx of calcium into the cell.
  • Irreversible cell injury damages the plasma membrane, which then fails to maintain this gradient, allowing the influx of calcium into the cell.

The other choices would most likely be released upon cell death. Diagnosis: Coagulative necrosis

questions.text: A 54-year-old chronic alcoholic presents to the emergency room with 12 hours of severe abdominal pain. The pain radiates to the back and is associated with an urge to vomit. Physical examination discloses exquisite abdominal tenderness. Laboratory studies show elevated serum amylase. Which of following morphologic changes would be expected in the peripancreatic tissue of this patient?
questions.solution:
Fat necrosis.

  • Saponification of fat derived from peripancreatic fat cells exposed to pancreatic enzymes is a typical feature of fat necrosis.
  • Lipase, released from pancreatic acinar cells during an attack of acute pancreatitis, hydrolyzes fat into fatty acids and glycerol. Free fatty acids bind with calcium to form grossly visible white chalky areas, which is a process known as saponification.
  • Hypocalcemia is a typical finding in patients who had a recent bout of acute pancreatitis.

Fat necrosis in acute pancreatitis- areas of white chalky deposits represent foci of fat necrosis with calcium soap formation (saponification) at sites of lipid breakdown in the mesentery.

questions.text: A 63-year-old postmenopausal woman is diagnosed with early stage breast cancer, which is initially managed by partial mastectomy and radiation therapy. Her tumor was positive for expression of estrogen receptors. Which agent would you recommend to this patient to prevent relapse?

Anastrazole is an aromatase inhibitor used to inhibit estrogen synthesis in the adrenal gland, a principle source in postmenopausal women.

Anticancer drugs and supportive care agents that can be given orally are

  • Altretamine
  • Hydroxyurea
  • Thalidomide and lenalidomide
  • Testosterone receptor blockers e.gflutamide
  • SERMse.gtamoxifen
  • Aromatase inhibitors e.g. anastrozole
  • Allopurino
  • Leucovorin
  • Pilocarpine
  • Mesna

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is seen in the clinic with hypertension of 150/95 mm Hg (millimeters of mercury). His personal medical history and physical examination are otherwise unremarkable but his family history is positive for early deaths due to cardiovascular disease. A decision is made to treat his hypertension, starting with a calcium channel blocker. Blocker A in a dose of 5 mg produces the same decrease in blood pressure as 500 mg of blocker B. Which of the following predictions is most accurate?

choices.text: Blocker A will be more efficacious than blocker B
Blocker A will be about 100 times more potent than blocker B
Toxicity of blocker A will be less than that of blocker B
Blocker A will have a wider therapeutic window than blocker B

questions.solution: The drug producing the same response at lower dose is more potent. In this question, drug A is 100 times more potent than drug B. This data does not indicate anything about efficacy, safety or duration of action.

questions.text: A 16-year old girl presents with primary amenorrhea, on examination has a blind vaginal pouch with the absence of uterus. To confirm the diagnosis, karyotyping is advised, in which phase of the cell cycle it is done?
questions.solution:
Karyotyping

  • The study of chromosomes
  • Procedure to examine chromosomes is to arrest dividing cells in metaphase with mitotic spindle inhibitors (e.g., N-diacetyl-N-methylcolchicine [Colcemid]) and then to stain (Giemsa stain) the chromosomes.
  • In a metaphase spread, the individual chromosomes take the form of two chromatids connected at the centromere.

questions.text: A patient with hyperuricemia is placed on an "antigout" drug. Before starting the drug you measure the total uric acid (amount, not concentration) in a 24-hour urine sample and then do the same several weeks after continued drug therapy at therapeutic doses. The post-treatment sample shows a significant reduction in urate content. There were no new pathologies developing during therapy, and the patient's daily purine intake did not change at all. What drug most likely accounted for these findings?
questions.solution:
• Allopurinol and febuxostat are uric acid synthesis inhibitors
    • Recommended as first-line agents for patients with CKD
  • Naproxen is an NSAIDs,
    • Marketed as active single S(–) enantiomer preparation, which poses less renal burden
    • But not used for chronic treatment
  • Sulfinpyrazone and Probenecid are uricosuric drugs not used in renal failure

questions.text: A 45 year old patient presented with diarrhoea, weight loss, and arthalgia. Intestinal biopsy was performed and diagram of which is given below. Based on the histological features what is your diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria.
  • The macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presented with history of bouts of cough and respiratory difficulty since 3-4 months. Picture of cytological examination of sputum is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In above image, eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals are seen.
  • The latter are composed of an eosinophil protein called galectin-10.
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals are seen in allergic reactions (asthma, bronchitis, allergic rhinitis and rhinosinusitis) and parasitic infections such as Ascariasis (parasitic pneumonia).
  • The cardinal symptoms of an asthmatic attack include chest tightness, dyspnea, wheezing, and coughing (with or without sputum production).
  • In asthma, eosinophils, Curschmann spirals, and Charcot-Leyden crystals can be seen in the sputum.

questions.text: A 26 year old male presented with fever, chills, night sweats and diarrhoea. The physician is suspecting malaria to be the diagnosis. ‘Dipstick test’ for rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum is based on which of the following protein?
questions.solution:
‘Dipstick test’is used for the rapid diagnosis of plasmodium falciparum:

  • Is a ‘rapid whole blood immunochromatographic test’.
  • Uses 2 antibodies specific for ‘Pf Histidine Rich Protein II antigen’.
  • Is a ‘antigen capture assay’.

ALSO REMEMBER:

  • Serological diagnosis of Kala Azar is based on: rk39 antigen.
  • Serological diagnosis of Dengue is based on: NS-1 antigen.

questions.text: A near-term Pregnant woman, was referred to you as a case of Anemia complicating Pregnancy with Hb = 4.9 gm/dl. 2 units of Blood transfusion done patient improved clinically. Post transfusion Hb = 7.8 gm/dl, the patient was advised to have iron-rich foods and prescribed Tablets of Folic acid and Ferrous sulfate. Along with these which of the following will you prescribe to increase iron absorption?
questions.solution:

  • Iron absorption is increased by
    • Acids [HCL]
    • Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C), citric acid
    • Amino acids containing SH-group
    • Sugars in the diet
  • Phytates, Tannates (found in tea), tetracyclines & Plant foods (non-heme iron) decreases iron absorption

questions.text: A 5 year old baby was brought to the hospital to get vaccinated by his mother. According to the latest guidelines of vaccination, which of the following is applicable for this age?
questions.solution:
According to Latest National immunization Schedule - NIS 2020-21:

  • Total 3 doses of DPT vaccine each at 6,10 & 14 weeks; & 2 booster doses each at [16-24 months] & 5yrs of age are given respectively.
  • Vitamin A should be started at 9months of age [1 lakh IU] & given for every 6months [2 lakh IU each] till 5yrs of age.
  • Hence DPT booster & Vit A are applicable at the age of 5 yrs.
  • 5 doses of OPV is completed with in 16-24months of age normally ; only in delayed immunization, it can be given till 5yrs of age.
  • Other recent changes in immunization guidelines in India:

  • 2 doses of Measles vaccine:-
    • first dose: 9 months of age.
    • second dose: 16-24 months age.
  • 2 doses of JE Live vaccine:
    • First dose : 9-12 months.
    • Second dose =16-24 months.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient having complaints of repeated episodes of reflux and heart burn. Esophageal biopsy was performed and shown below. What is your diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • These are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus, and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue by hematoxylin and eosin and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.

questions.text: Disease prevention is a procedure through which individuals, particularly those with risk factors for a disease, are treated in order to prevent a disease from occurring. The most cost-effective mode of intervention for prevention of disease is which among the following?
questions.solution:
• Health education is one of the most cost- effective interventions.
  • A large number of diseases could be prevented if people were adequately informed & if they were encouraged to take necessary precautions in time.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male comes in to your clinic with a 4.5cm long superficial cut wound. You decide to suture it yourself, take consent and ask the nurse to bring a local anaesthetic. Local anaesthetics act by inhibiting –
questions.solution: Local anaesthetic is injected around the injured tissue via sub cutaneous route. There is presence of blood vessels in sub cutaneous area, so on injecting local anaesthetic subcutaneously some of LA may enter the blood vessel and now along with blood it goes away making LA short acting and also it reaches to other vital organs like brain, heart producing arrhythmias, convulsions and other systemic side effects. Local anaesthesia acts by inhibiting motor and sensory fibres.

questions.text: A sexually active female came with green coloured profuse frothy foul-smelling discharge with intense itching. O/E strawberry cervix revealed. What condition she belongs to?

Trichomoniasis

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with long-standing angina pectoris and arterial hypertension dies of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage. At autopsy, the heart appears globoid. The left ventricle measures 2.8 cm on cross-section (shown in the image). This adaptation to chronic injury was mediated primarily by changes in the intracellular concentration of which of the following components?
questions.solution:
The answer is D: mRNA.

Hypertrophic cardiac myocytes have more cytoplasm and larger nuclei than normal cells. Although the elucidation of the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the hypertrophic response is still actively pursued, it is clear that the final steps include increases in mRNA,rRNA, and protein.
The muscle cell synthesises more proteins and number of myofilaments increases.

Hypertrophy results from transcriptional regulation.


Diagnosis: Hypertrophic heart disease.

questions.text: During the autopsy of a homicide victim, the doctor notices a circular wound on the left temporal area with a crater-like outer table and a punched-out inner table. There is no evidence of singing of hair or tattooing present. There are also tissue tags along the irregular edges of the wound. What type of wound is the doctor observing?
questions.solution:
Gunshot wounds on Skull:

  • Skull has an outer table & inner table.
  • When the bullet enters the skull, bevelling occurs in the second layer.
  • In entry wound, the bevelling is present in the inner table of skull.
  • In exit wound, the bevelling is present in the outer table of skull.
  • Entry wound: shows a punched-out hole (clean cut) on the outer table and bevelled (crater) appearance on the inner table.
  • Exit wound: the inner table shows clean-cut hole and the outer table shows bevelling since the bullet is leaving so the outer table is raised.
Entry wound Exit wound
Skull Outer table Clean cut hole Bevelled opening
Skull Inner table Bevelled opening Clean cut hole

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman was brought to a hospital emergency department by her brother. Visiting the halfway house in which she lived, he had found her to be lethargic, with slurred speech. The patient had a long history of treatment for depression, and the brother feared that she might have overdosed on 1 or more of her prescription drugs. Physical examination reveals hypotension, tachycardia, decreased bowel sounds, dilated pupils, and hyperthermia. If this patient has taken a drug overdose, the most likely causative agent is

• Tricyclic antidepressants (TCA) possess anticholinergic and sedative properties.
  • Amitriptyline and tryptamine possess highest sedative, hypotension, tachycardia and antimuscarinic actions such as decreased bowel sounds and pupillary dilatation. In severe overdose, watch for the ‘’3 Cs’’ Coma, Convulsions and Cardiotoxicity.

What is the Positive predictive value?
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value of a test is the number of true-positives divided by the total number of people with a positive test result. In this case,

Positive Predictive Value:

A/(A + B) × 100

10/50 × 100 = 20%

Clinically, positive predictive value depends on the prevalence of disease. Diseases with a low prevalence have low positive predictive values thus clinicians often have to work up healthy patients with positive screening tests

B is not correct

Negative Predictive Value: D/(D + C) × 100

45/50 × 100 = 90%

C is not correct

Sensitivity is calculated by taking the number of true-positives divided by the number of people with the disease. Sensitivity is two-thirds, so the test is able to detect two-thirds of the people with disease. The test misses one-third of the people who have disease.

Sensitivity:

A/(A + C) × 100

10/15 × 100 = 67%

D is not correct Specificity is calculated by taking the number of true-negatives divided by the number of people who are truly healthy.

The test has 53% specificity. In other words, 45 persons out of 85 persons with negative results are truly negative and 40 individuals test positive for a disease which they do not have.

Specificity:

D/(D + B) × 100

questions.text: A middle-aged businessman visits his primary care physician complaining of a purulent penile discharge. He had unprotected sex with a woman he met at a conference 1 week ago. Gram stain of the discharge fails to reveal any organisms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the discharge?
questions.solution:
• C. trachomatis is one of the leading causes of urethritis and should be suspected whenever a gonorrhea-like discharge fails to show gram-negative diplococci within neutrophilic phagocytes. It is a sexually transmitted disease that can also cause epididymitis.
  • Bowen disease presents as a single erythematous plaque on the penis or scrotum and may evolve into invasive carcinoma.
  • Herpes simplex virus can cause a vesicular rash on the penis.
  • T. pallidum causes syphilis, which may present with a painless chancre on the penis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient was found unconscious under a tree and was brought to the emergency department where he regained consciousness. He said that he had taken shelter under a tree during a storm. He also said that he had remembered nothing after the sound of the lightning. His hearing and the tympanic membrane were found to be normal. There were significant Lichtenberg figures on the patient's back, extending over the right scapula. These characteristic burns are also known as?
questions.solution:
• Filigree burns or Arborescent or fern-like injury or Lichtenberg figures
    • Pathognomonic for lightning injury
    • Superficial, irregular red marks, may follow skin creases, especially if damp from sweating. (fern-like pattern).
    • The erythematous marks are not burns.

Cause: Different authors have suggested different causes

  • The lesion occurs when an individual struck by a negative lightning bolt is then hit by a secondary positive flashover from a nearby grounded object.
  • It represents an entrance point in an individual struck by a positively charged lightning bolt.
  • Slight staining of tissues by haemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.

Option 1, Crocodile flash burns: Multiple burnt or punched-out lesions are produced due to the air dancing over the body surface over large areas.

Option 2, Adipocere: a variation of putrefaction. It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in damp, warm environments. In adipocere, fat undergoes hydrolysis to free fatty acids by virtue of endogenous lipases and bacterial enzymes.

Option 3, Mummification: Another modified form of putrefaction, where drying and desiccation of the tissues occur instead of liquefaction, depending upon the conditions prevalent at the terminal stages.

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient presents with complaints of having persistent allergic rhinitis, asthmatic episodes with peripheral hypereosinophilia. Histological findings are shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above image shows eosinophil-rich vasculitis.
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome is a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis classically associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomas.
  • Vascular lesions can be histologically similar to polyarteritis nodosa or microscopic polyangiitis but are also characteristically accompanied by granulomas and eosinophils.

questions.text: A three years old male child, presented with mild pallor, icterus, and a history of on and off abdominal and joint pains. On examination, the child had mild splenomegaly. He had a history of two prior hospital admissions. He has had three transfusions till now, the last transfusion was 3 months back. There is a history of sibling death at 5 years of age due to fever and jaundice. The hemogram showed anemia with leukocytosis. The peripheral smear is done of which images are shown below. which of the following is true about the finding?

choices.text: Fetal hemoglobin facilitates this type of finding
It is associated with reduced MCHC
It occurs equally in both heterozygous and homozy­gous variants

questions.solution:
• Sickle cell disease is a common familial hemolytic anemia caused by a point mutation in β-globin in which glutamic acid is replaced by valine at 6th position.
  • It promotes the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin, leading to red cell distortion, hemolytic anemia, microvascular obstruction, and ischemic tissue damage.
  • This sickling is reversible with oxygenation.
  • Sickling is severe in homozygous state than heterozygous state.
  • HbS facilitates sickling, not HbF
  • Dehydration [high MCHC] & deoxygenation, Acidosis and Infections facilitates sickling.
  • Alkalosis does not facilitate sickling.
  • Peripheral smear showing sickle cells, elliptocytes and ovalocytes
  • Sickling test positive.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the hospital by ambulance following a car accident causing serious head injuries. His blood pressure is 220/170 mmHg. Fundoscopy reveals retinal damage, and you administer nitroprusside via infusion. Control of the hypertension requires 72 hours and you notice the patient becoming increasingly fatigued and nauseous. The mostly likely cause of these symptoms is

choices.text: Accumulation of nitroprusside because of its long half-life

questions.solution:
• Sodium nitroprusside and hydralazine act by releas­ing nitric oxide from the endothelium, which in turn increases intracellular cGMP by stimulation of guany­lyl cyclase leading to vasodilation.
  • Nitroprusside, in addition can directly stimulate guanylyl cyclaseto cause increase in cGMP.
  • Nitroprusside is avery short acting drug; therefore has to be administered byconstant i.v. infusionfor the treatment ofhypertensive emergencies.
  • Its solution should be freshly prepared because it is unstable andsensitive to light.
  • Prolonged administration of this drug can result in accumulation ofcyanideleading totoxicityparticu­larly in patients with renal disease.
  • It can also result inhypothyroidismdue to the accumu­lation of thiocyanate (antithyroid compound).
  • It iscontra-indicated in pregnancy

The most rational choice for specifically antagonizing the consequence of hormone excess aldosterone being the hormone of most important in terms of the renal, hemodynamic and electrolyte problems here is spironolactone

Spironolactone:

  • Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist

questions.text: The term 'gateway drug' is often used because using it leaves people susceptible to unknowingly ingest other substances. Experts have long warned of the dangers of the substance being laced with harmful drugs such as PCP, crack, or cocaine. It is known for its typical "burned rope" odor. questions.solution:
Smell about mouth & Nose-

  1. Garlic-like - Phosphorus, Arsenic, Organophosphates, Thallium, Selenium, Dimethylsulphoxide.
  2. Sweetish or fruity - Ethanol, Chloroform, Nitrites.
  3. Acrid (pear-like) - Paraldehyde, Chloral hydrate.

questions.text: A 38-year-old Bengali man presents with complaints of multiple papular lesions over the body especially involving the palms and soles. The lesions are not painful. He has pigmentation of skin over the abdomen. He also has vertical white ridges over the nails. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Arsenic poisoning

  • Necrosis of intestinal mucosa with hemorrhagic gastroenteritis,
  • Hypotension,
  • Delayed cardiomyopathy,
  • Acute tubular necrosis,
  • Hemolysis.
  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, delirium, coma, seizures;
  • Garlicky odor on breath;
  • Hyperkeratosis, hyperpigmentation, exfoliative dermatitis,
  • Mees’ lines (transverse white striae of the fingernails)
  • Sensory and motor polyneuritis, distal weakness.

EPIDERMODYSPLASIAVERRUCIFORMIS:

  • The lesions resemble flat warts or macules similar to those of pityriasis Versicolor. In patients with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, squamous cell cancers develop frequently at sites infected with specific HPV types, including 5 and 8.

LICHEN PLANUS

  • Lichen planus (LP) is a papulosquamous disorder in which the primary lesions are pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules.

XERODERMA PIGMENTOSUM (XP)

  • An autosomal recessive disorder Characterized by variably deficient repair of UV-induced photoproducts.
  • Their skin phenotype often manifests the dry, leathery appearance of prematurely photoaged skin as well as basal cell and squamous cell carcinomas and melanoma in the first two decades of life.

questions.text: A study shows that subjects with history of smoking had a relative risk of 3.2 compared to the control group {95% confidence interval 2.2-4.2) for developing lung cancer. The investigators came to a conclusion that history of smoking that significantly increases the risk for lung cancer. Which statement is accurate with regard to the conclusion of the study?

choices.text: Results of the study are highly specific
Relative risk cannot be calculated from this study; therefore, the conclusions are invalid
P value for the confidence interval would be <0.05
Attributable risk of lung cancer following smoking is 3.2

questions.solution:
Relative risk compares the risk of developing a disease in an exposed population to the disease risk in an unexposed population. If the CI includes 1.0, then the results of the study show no significant difference between the two groups. If the CI does not include 1.0, then the P value, the chance of making a type I error, must be <0.05

A IS NOT CORRECT Specificity is the number of true negatives 1 (true negatives + false positives). This cannot be determined from the information given.

B IS NOT CORRECT cohort studies because they are prospective and can determine causality so relative risk can be calculated from it. In retrospective case-control studies the relative risk, but not the odds ratio, can be calculated.

D IS NOT CORRECT Attributable risk refers to the absolute number of cases that can be attributed with risk factor. The attributable risk would be 2.2 in this study. In this case, the exposed group is 3.2 times more likely to get Lung cancer. There is people who are likely to get cancer in the unexposed group. Attributable risk can be calculated from the relative risk using the formula: Attributable risk = relative risk - 1.

questions.text: An indian drug company is studying a process of testing a new drug COVAXIN, The phase I/II study found that covaxin is safe, immunogenic with no serious side effects with high neutralizing antibody responses. It also reported that number of participants with adverse effects was significantly lower in phase ii trial than in phase I. The new medication has been tested against the current standard of care. Covaxin has been found to be efficacious. What factor puts this medication in phase III of drug trials?

choices.text: Comparing it to the current standard of care

questions.solution:
Although the rest of the choices are necessary to complete phases I and II of drug testing, it is the comparison to the current standard of care that places in this trial in phase III. The drug may be safe and efficacious.

A is not correct

Phase II trial focuses on a small number of patients with the disease for whom the drug will be used. The adverse effects for a drug should be established in phase II trials

B is not correct The pharmacokinetics are assessed in phase I trials, and the optimal dosing is assessed in phase II trials.

C is not correct The efficacy of the medication is said to be established in phase II trials

questions.text: The defending team has appealed to the judge to make the information gathered during an inquiry as invalid as the concerned team had not followed the protocols as defined under CrPC 174. Which team's inquiry does the defendant's team have concerns about?
questions.solution:
Important CrPC:

  • 2 CrPC: Gives various definitions (Bailable and non-bailable offence, Cognizable and Non-Cognizable Offence, summons and warrant case etc.)
  • 39CrPC: Public to give information of certain offences (e.g. Homicide, kidnapping, robbery etc.) to nearest Magistrate or police officer
  • 53 CrPC: Examination of accused by medical practitioner at the request of police officer (Doctor can examine the arrested person even without his consent)
  • 54 CrPC: Arrested person can himself request the magistrate for his medical examination to get evidence in his favour.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of bloody stools. His BP was constantly lowering and he was showing symptoms of shock. The patient gave a history of consumption of pork and raw sausages. Which of the following organism is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical condition is suggestive of Pigbel, caused by by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Clostridium perfringens:
    • 13 major & minor toxins are present.
    • Type A – E
    • Most infections are caused by Type A/α toxin.
  • Causes:
    • Gas gangrene: Pain, crepitus.
    • Food poisoning: due to contaminated meat products. Incubation period is 8-24 hrs.
  • Pigbel:
    • due to uncooked pork consumption.
    • Causes necrotizing enteritis.
    • due to beta toxin Type C.
    • Characterized by abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, shock, and peritonitis.
    • Severe and often fatal.
    • Also known as “Pigbel”in Papua New Guinea and as “Darmbrand” (meaning “fire bowels”) in Germany.
  • Reactions of Clostridium perfringens:
    • Naegler's reaction
    • Stormy fermentation in litmus milk
    • Target haemolysis
    • Reverse CAMP test

Answers to other options:

Option 1: Echinococcus (dog tapeworm): causes cystic echinococcosis, also known ashydatid disease.

Option 2:T. saginata (beef tapeworm): Intestinal taeniasis.

Option 4:Clostridium tetani: causes tetanus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the rheumatology outpatient clinic with a three month history of stiff hands and wrists. She mentions that the pain is particularly bad first thing in the morning. On examination, the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalyngeal joints are swollen and warm. A diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis is suspected. Which of the following investigations is most specific for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Anti-citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies levels are the most specific investigation for rheumatoid arthritis.

X-rays (A) early in the disease course will demonstrate soft tissue swelling but are unlikely to show much else. However, x-rays of the hands, feet and any other affected joint should be performed early in the disease to establish a baseline.

Rheumatoid factor (B) is positive in approximately 70 per cent of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. However, it is not specific to rheumatoid arthritis and may be raised in a number of other conditions.

Rheumatoid factor should be tested for in patients with suspected rheumatoid arthritis. Anti-CCP antibodies can be subsequently sent if rheumatoid factor is negative or to inform decision making about starting therapy. It is important to note that anti-CCP antibodies are not presently a routine test for all patients with suspected rheumatoid arthritis.

C-reactive protein (D) is raised in many infective and inflammatory conditions. It is therefore not the most specific test for rheumatoid arthritis. However, it is raised in rheumatoid arthritis and can be used to monitor the disease and guide treatment decisions.

questions.text: A woman, 29 years old, gravida 2 para 1, at 40 weeks gestation age, was admitted to hospital with complaint of lower abdominal pain. The patient was transferred to labour room for delivery and was given paracervical block. This relieves pain from all of the following except:

choices.text: Pain from dilatation of the cervix
Relieve pain from the upper third of vagina
Relives pain from the lower third of vagina and episiotomy can be performed

questions.solution:
Paracervical block relieves pain from the upper third of the Vagina, not the lower third.

Paracervical block

Basis of use: Sensory nerve fibers from the uterus fuse bilaterally at the 4-6 O'clock and 6-8 O'clock position around the cervix in the region of cervicovaginal junction.

  • In paracervical block, 5-10 ml of 1% lidocaine is injected into these areas to interrupt the sensory input from the cervix and uterus.
  • It relieves the pain of uterine contractions
  • Since the block is given in lateral fornix so it anesthetizes the upper 1/3rd of the vagina also.
  • It is not useful at the time of episiotomy as the lower part of the vagina is not anesthetized.
  • It is no longer considered safe as it causes fetal bradycardia.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman, in whom a bulky vulvar mass in the left labia majora was detected during cystoscopy for urinary symptoms, was referred to the gynecology clinic. Histological analysis of the mass confirmed a benign Bartholin's cyst. All are true about this condition except:

choices.text: Swelling is present characteristically on the inner side of the junction of the anterior 2/3 rd with posterior 1/3 rd of the labium majus
Left Bartholins’ gland is more often affected than the right
It is believed that the infection responsible is invariably gonococcal
Usually presents as a unilateral swelling that bulges across the vaginal introitus

questions.solution:
Bartholin's cyst:

  • It is the most common cyst of the vulva.
  • Bartholins’ cysts is produced from the accumulation of secretions of Bartholin's gland.
  • The cyst may develop either in the duct (more common) or in the gland
  • Etiology: Cyst formation occurs due to the obstruction of the main duct or opening of an acinus.
  • The cause of obstruction is usually fibrosis which follows either infection or trauma.
  • It was formerly believed that the infection was invariably gonococcal but almost any organism can be responsible.
  • Left Bartholins’ gland is more often affected than the right.

Presentation:

  • Usually presents as a unilateral swelling that bulges across the vaginal introitus.
  • Size of the cyst rarely exceeds hen’s egg.
  • Swelling is present characteristically on the inner side of the junction of the anterior 2/3 rd with posterior 1/3 rd of the labium majus.
  • The swelling is fluctuant and usually non-tender
  • Patient may present with discomfort, dyspareunia, or infection.

Treatment of choice is Marsupialization: It is preferred over traditional excision operations.

questions.text:
True about Effect of estrogen and progesterone on Uterus:

Estrogen aids estrogen in myometrial hypertrophy
Progesterone increase in the tortuosity of glands, ↑ lipid, and glycogen deposits
Estrogen stimulates the synthesis of myometrial contractile protein actinomycin through cAMP
Progesterone dominated uterus is also more sensitive to oxytocin
questions.solution:
Effect of estrogen and progesterone on Uterus:

Effect of estrogen Effect of progesterone
  • Estrogen causes marked proliferation of the endometrial stroma and greatly increased development of the endometrial glands
  • Estrogen causes hypertrophy of the myometrium.
  • Estrogen stimulates the synthesis of myometrial contractile protein actinomycin through cAMP. Under the influence of estrogens, the muscles become more active and excitable and action potentials in the individual fibers become more frequent.
  • The estrogen dominated uterus is also more sensitive to oxytocin
  • Promote secretory changes in the uterine endometrium during the latter half of the monthly female sexual cycle, thus prepares the uterus for implantation of the fertilized ovum.
  • It aids estrogen in myometrial hypertrophy
  • Increase in the tortuosity of glands
  • ↑ lipid and glycogen deposits
  • Decreases the frequency and intensity of uterine contractions, thereby helping to prevent expulsion of the implanted ovum but increases the amplitude of contraction.

questions.text: Clamping and cutting of the umbilical cord at birth is by far the oldest and most prevalent intervention in humans. In spite of that, the optimal timing of cord clamping has been a controversial issue for decades. There are no formal practice guidelines, but most practitioners in western countries clamp and cut the cord immediately after birth, while the practice worldwide is variable. In our country, immediate cord ligation is done for all except:
questions.solution:
Early cord clamping is advised/practiced in case of:

  1. Preterm or growth-restricted fetus (due to the risk of hypervolemia).
  2. In Rh isoimmunisation (to minimize even minute amount of antibody to cross to the fetus from the mother).
  3. Birth asphyxia.
  4. HIV-positive mother.
  5. Infants of diabetic mother In case of Rh isoimmunisation:
  • No prophylactic ergometrine should be given:
  • The cord should be kept long (2-3cms) to enable exchange transfusion if required.
  • Cord blood sample should be taken from the placental end for:
    • ABO and Rh grouping
    • Direct Coombs test
    • Measurement of serum bilirubin
    • Hemoglobin estimation
    • Blood smear for presence of immature RBCs.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who is in her second pregnancy with no history of GDM was seen for prenatal care at 30 weeks gestation. The patient's past obstetric history includes the spontaneous vaginal delivery of a male infant at 40 weeks gestation, 8 years ago. Her family history reveals that her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. A urine dipstick of the patient showed 3+ glycosuria and negative ketones. The hyperglycemic state of this patient would possibly cause the following condition in the infant:
questions.solution:
• Hyperglycemia at the time of conception results in enhanced rates of spontaneous abortion and major congenital malformations.
  • Hyperglycemia in later pregnancy increases the risk for macrosomia, hypocalcemia, polycythemia, respiratory difficulties, cardiomyopathy, and congestive heart failure.

Macrosomia

  • Fetal macrosomia is defined by ACOG as fetal birth weight is > 4500 g.
  • Macrosomic fetuses have extensive fat deposits on the shoulder and trunk which is associated with increased incidence of shoulder dystocia.
  • Organ which is not affected in macrosomia is brain.
  • Control of postprandial blood sugar levels is very important for preventing macrosomia.
  • For diagnosing macrosomia: USG is performed every 4 weeks, starting at 20 weeks of gestation.
  • First sign of developing macrosomia is: increase in abdominal circumference more than other measurements.
  • Management: If wt of the fetus is > 4.5 kg in diabetic mothers or > 5 kg in non-diabetic mothers C–section is recommended

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to accident and emergency with severe right flank pain. The pain started 3 hours ago and is not constant, occasionally moving towards her right iliac fossa. The patient also feels nauseous and has a low-grade fever. The most appropriate investigation is:
questions.solution:
(A) This patient has a suspected renal stone, the initial investigation would be an abdominal ultrasound scan specifically of the kidneys, ureters and bladder (KUB). The differential diagnosis should include other causes of abdominal pain, such as acute appendicitis. The most common stone consists of calcium oxalate and up to 80 per cent of renal stones are visible on ultrasound. The KUB US scan is poor at differentiating different stones and can often miss smaller stones. It is not as sensitive as CT and images only the kidney and possibly the proximal segment of the ureter; thus most ureteral stones are not detectable by ultrasound.

(C) is more useful for detecting obstructions in the renal tract and US scans should always be done before IVU as smaller stones often become nonvisible. IVU is also more invasive than US scanning with particular risk from contrast-induced damage and radiation.

(D) is superior to IVU and US scans as it is able to differentiate up to 99 per cent of renal stones and it is also useful for exploring other causes of an acute abdomen.

(B) has only a few advantages over a CT scan, these include the ability to assess renal arteries and there is no risk from radiation. However, MRI has poor differentiation ability and stones can often appear similar to tumours or blood clots. Where it is particularly important to avoid radiation, i.e. a pregnant woman, an MRI scan should be considered.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presented to your clinic with a painful, red left eye, photophobia, tearing, and decreased visual acuity. The medical history highlighted a possible corneal abrasion due to intense scratching and the use of tap water to wash the eyes. A right eye slit lamp examination was normal, while a left eye slit-lamp examination showed a marked ciliary injection and diffuse corneal edema. The probable pathogen involved in this condition would be:
questions.solution:
ACANTHAMOEBA KERATITIS

  • Acanthamoeba is free lying amoeba seen in soil, fresh water, sewage
  • Seen in contact lens wearers & contamination or inoculation with soil or muddy water or trauma with organic matter
  • Transparent colonies in non-nutrient agar.

C/F

  • Initial photophobia to excessive pain in established infection
  • Epithelial ridges & Pseudodendrites
  • Ring of Wessley
  • Radial Keratoneuritis & Stromal satellite infiltrates
  • Ring abscess with hypopyon and necrosis
  • Pain out of proportion to the signs Can mimic fungal corneal ulcer Ix
  • Confocal
  • Non-nutrient agar
  • High deal of suspicion in non-responding ulcers

Rx

  • PHMB (DOC) &Pentamidine is indicated in treatment.
  • Symptomatic treatment to be started
  • Clotrimazole
  • Long treatment for 1 year for stromal lessons PK in non-responding cases

questions.text: A 52-year-old white, nonsmoking man who worked in a research chemical laboratory, presented with complaints of throat pain and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, a right tonsillar mass measuring 2.7 x 3.6 cm was noted. The patient was scheduled for a tonsillectomy and during the procedure there was hemorrhage. The most common cause of bleeding during this procedure is:

  • M/C arterial cause of bleeding or M/C cause of torrential bleeding during tonsillectomy: Tonsillar branch of facial artery (called as the artery of tonsillar hemorrhage)

questions.text: Pick the correctly matched causes of the cataract in the given option :

questions.text: A 60 years old male with poor stream of urine, post-void residual urine is 400 ml, bilateral hydronephrosis, and prostate weighing 70g. His urea is 120 and creatinine 3.5 ideal “next immediate” step:
questions.solution: • Catheterization is mandatory for acute urinary retentionQ. Spontaneous voiding may return, but a catheter should be left indwelling for 3 days while detrusor tone returns.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of right calf pain and swelling. She further complained of shortness of breath and sharp chest pain. She underwent a left hemicolectomy for diverticular disease. The physical examination shows unilateral leg swelling. The physician made the diagnosis based on signs and symptoms. What is the most appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Heparin

  • In the above-given case, the sign and symptoms of right calf pain and swelling, shortness of breath, sharp chest pain, and unilateral leg swelling indicates the diagnosis of Deep venous thrombosis (DVT).
  • Anticoagulants can be used for the management of DVT.
  • The drug of choice is IV Heparin for 5 days.
  • Warfarin can also be started, which acts after 72 hours (from the 3rd day onwards, dose adjustment is required).

 

Option A: Pneumatic compression stockings

  • Pneumatic compression stockings are used to prevent blood clotting.
  • These stockings are not recommended after DVT.

Option C: Thrombolysis

  • Thrombolysis is not recommended in DVT due to the low risk of post-thrombotic syndrome.
  • For the management of DVT, the drugs such as urokinase, streptokinase, and tissue plasminogen activator are injected directly at the site of the clot.

Option D: Inferior vena cava filter

  • An inferior vena cava filter is used for the prevention of DVT, not for the management of DVT.
  • DVT is the delayed complication of the inferior vena cava filter.

questions.text: False about Eustachian tube:

choices.text: In an adult ET, retrograde reflux of nasopharyngeal Secretion can occur
At birth it forms an angle of 10° with the horizontal. At age 7 and later it is 45°
Density of elastin is more and helps to keep the tube closed by recoil of cartilage
Ostmann’s pad of fat is less in volume in infants

questions.solution:
Infant Adult
Length 13–18 mm birth (about half as long as in adult) 36 mm (31–38 mm)
Direction More horizontal, At birth it forms an angle of 10° with the horizontal. At age 7 and later it is 45° Forms an angle of 45° with the horizonal
Angulation at isthmus No angulation Angulation persent

Tubal cartilaginous part Flaccid. Retrograde reflux of nasopharyngeal secretion can occur Comparatively rigid, Remains closed and protects middle ear from reflux.
Density of elastin at the hinge Less dense; tube does not efficiently close by recoil Density of elastin more and helps to keep the tube closed by recoil of cartilage
Ostmann’s pad of fat Less in volume Large and helps to keep the tube closed

questions.text: Front office manager reports that the person who has walked into the office for an interview has an ulterior motive to sabotage the manager’s life in the organization and hence come over to office to persecute him. In this delusion, the patient believes that someone unknown and stranger to him is actually a persecutor in disguise, out there to get him. questions.text: A 60 years old chronic smoker presented with jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss. ERCP was done. The diagnosis based on the sign shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
• The image shows a double duct sign, which is characteristic of the carcinoma head of the pancreas.

Radiological signs of Ca PANCREAS

  1. Double contour of medial border of duodenal C loop
  2. Double duct sign →CA head of pancreas(Mass effect causes upstream pancreatic and biliary duct dilation)
  3. Dilated/ Widening of duodenal C loop
  4. Mucosal irregularity
  5. Scrambled egg appearance
  6. Inverted / reverse 3 sign of Frostberg.
  7. Rose thorning of medial wall of 2nd part of duodenum. (Ampullary carcinoma)

Ca head of pancreas - 3 signs

  • Double Duct
  • Reverse 3 sign of Frostberg
  • Antral pad sign

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was admitted in ICU with a history of high-grade fever, cough, myalgia, loss of sensation of smell for the past one week. His blood pressure-100/60 mmHg; pulse rate-110/min; SpO2-90%; respiratory rate-25/minute; temperature-102oF and his chest x-ray showed peripheral ground-glass opacities in both lungs. He was treated with 15 liters/minute of oxygen through non-rebreathing mask, antibiotics, and steroids. Maximum FiO2 range delivered to this patient is?
questions.solution:
• Anesthetic face mask delivers 100% oxygen.
  • These facemasks have acuffthat allows for a complete seal to be achieved between the mask and the patient's face.
  • Anesthetic facemasks can therefore be used to deliver non-invasive ventilation (NIV).In order to ventilate with an anesthetic facemask you'll need apressurized gas source(anesthesia gas supplies)such as a cylinder or gas wall supply.
  • If no pressurized gas source is available, a self-inflating bag will allow for positive pressure-ventilation through an anesthetic facemask.
  • The cuff volume can typically be adjusted through a valve.
  • A somewhat under-inflated cuff usually achieves a better seal than a fully inflated one.
  • Most manufacturers supply these masks with a detachablehook ringwhich allows for the mask to be held in place with a head strap for delivering NIV.

  • Anaesthetic facemasks are generally used in two different settings/ scenarios:
  • 1. For bag-mask ventilation (BMV) in the resuscitation setting.
  • 2. To provide non-invasive ventilation (NIV) or respiratory support, most commonly as either continuous or biphasic positive airway pressure (CPAP or BIPAP) in patients with respiratory compromise.
  • The nasal cannulahas two prongs that are placed in the patient's nostrils and deliver oxygen at flow rates of1 to 6 litresper minute and deliver approximately24 to 44 percent of oxygen to the patient.
System or device Oxygen flow rate(l/min) Reservoir volume(ml) Fio2 range Fio2 Variability
Low flow nasal O2 1-6 - 24-40 variable
Standard face mask 5-10 100-200 35-50 variable
Partial rebreather mask >10 600-1000 40-70 variable
Nonrebreather mask >10 600-1000 60-80 variable
Air entrainment mask >60 100-200 24-50 constant
High flow nasal O2 Less than or equal to 40 - 21-100 variable
